Speaker: Narrator
Text: In this study you will read a description of a criminal case and give your opinions about it. Although it is based on a real case, some of the facts (and all of the names) have been changed for the purposes of the study.</br></br> As when listening to testimony, you will not be able to go back. Please use the notepad to keep track of relevant information.
combined:
In this study you will read a description of a criminal case and give your opinions about it. Although it is based on a real case, some of the facts (and all of the names) have been changed for the purposes of the study.

As when listening to testimony, you will not be able to go back. Please use the notepad to keep track of relevant information.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: In this case, the defendant - Richard Cole - has been charged with willfully discharging a firearm in a place of business. This crime is a felony. </br></br> Mr. Cole has pleaded not guilty to the charge. </br></br> You will now read a summary of the case. This summary was prepared by an objective court clerk. It describes select evidence that was presented at trial.
combined:
In this case, the defendant - Richard Cole - has been charged with willfully discharging a firearm in a place of business. This crime is a felony.

Mr. Cole has pleaded not guilty to the charge.

You will now read a summary of the case. This summary was prepared by an objective court clerk. It describes select evidence that was presented at trial.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: Police received a 911 call from a convenience store clerk stating that a man had entered the store, pulled out a firearm, fired a shot into the ceiling, and then demanded money. The man ended up leaving the store without receiving any money and no one was hurt by the gunshot. </br></br> The store clerk took the stand and stated that she did not get a close enough look at the robber's face to make an identification, because the robber wore a ski mask.</br></br> As the cashier was pulling out the money to hand to him, she pressed a hidden button that activated an alarm and called the police. Startled by the alarm bells, the robber rushed out of the store. </br></br> Next, the detective testified that he arrived at the convenience store and interviewed the clerk. The detective recovered the 9mm bullet from the ceiling of the store, which was collected for forensic analysis. </br></br> Two days later, a police officer pulled over Richard Cole for speeding. During a search of the Defendant's vehicle, the detective located a 9mm handgun, which was legally licensed to the Defendant. Because this gun was the same caliber as the one used in the convenience store shooting, it was confiscated for testing. Richard Cole was subsequently arrested and charged with willfully discharging a firearm in a place of business.
combined:
Police received a 911 call from a convenience store clerk stating that a man had entered the store, pulled out a firearm, fired a shot into the ceiling, and then demanded money. The man ended up leaving the store without receiving any money and no one was hurt by the gunshot.

The store clerk took the stand and stated that she did not get a close enough look at the robber's face to make an identification, because the robber wore a ski mask.

As the cashier was pulling out the money to hand to him, she pressed a hidden button that activated an alarm and called the police. Startled by the alarm bells, the robber rushed out of the store.

Next, the detective testified that he arrived at the convenience store and interviewed the clerk. The detective recovered the 9mm bullet from the ceiling of the store, which was collected for forensic analysis.

Two days later, a police officer pulled over Richard Cole for speeding. During a search of the Defendant's vehicle, the detective located a 9mm handgun, which was legally licensed to the Defendant. Because this gun was the same caliber as the one used in the convenience store shooting, it was confiscated for testing. Richard Cole was subsequently arrested and charged with willfully discharging a firearm in a place of business.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: You will now read a transcript of testimony given by Terry Smith at trial.
combined: You will now read a transcript of testimony given by Terry Smith at trial.

Text: Your next witness, please

Text: The People would call Terry Smith.

combined:

Text: The local police department.

Speaker: Pros
Text: What do you do for the police department?
combined: What do you do for the police department?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I am a firearms examiner.
combined: I am a firearms examiner.

Speaker: Pros
Text: How long have you been doing that?
combined: How long have you been doing that?

Speaker: Fire
Text: 7 years
combined: 7 years

Speaker: Pros
Text: What is a firearms examiner?
combined: What is a firearms examiner?

Speaker: Fire
Text: A firearms examiner is someone who looks at cartridge cases and bullets to determine whether they were fired from a particular firearm.
combined: A firearms examiner is someone who looks at cartridge cases and bullets to determine whether they were fired from a particular firearm.

Speaker: Pros
Text: What training is required to become a firearms examiner with the local police department?
combined: What training is required to become a firearms examiner with the local police department?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I received my bachelor's degree in forensic science and in 2015 I transferred to the crime lab from the crime scene unit. I underwent a two-year training program, which was supervised by experienced firearms examiners; I've toured manufacturing facilities and saw how firearms and ammunition were produced; and I've attended several national and regional meetings of firearms examiners.
combined: I received my bachelor's degree in forensic science and in 2015 I transferred to the crime lab from the crime scene unit. I underwent a two-year training program, which was supervised by experienced firearms examiners; I've toured manufacturing facilities and saw how firearms and ammunition were produced; and I've attended several national and regional meetings of firearms examiners.

Speaker: Pros
Text: And during the course of your career, were you tested in proficiency to make sure you were still conducting appropriate examinations?
combined: And during the course of your career, were you tested in proficiency to make sure you were still conducting appropriate examinations?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes. I have undergone annual proficiency examinations.
combined: Yes. I have undergone annual proficiency examinations.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Is the local police department lab accredited?
combined: Is the local police department lab accredited?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, it is accredited by ASCLID/LAB.
combined: Yes, it is accredited by ASCLID/LAB.

Speaker: Pros
Text: And in addition to what you just told us, do you have other qualifications?
combined: And in addition to what you just told us, do you have other qualifications?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, I do.
combined: Yes, I do.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Can you tell us what those are?
combined: Can you tell us what those are?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes. I received training in the use of a bullet matching algorithm. This is an algorithm that evaluates the characteristics of two fired bullets, in order to produce a score for the similarity of the bullets, where more similar bullets are more likely to have been fired from the same gun. I attended a workshop on the algorithm on 1/11/2020, held by CSAFE - Center for Statistics and Applications in Forensic Evidence. The training taught me to use the algorithm alongside my personal judgement. I found that my conclusion was reflected in the similarity score produced by the algorithm in all 21 cases.
combined: Yes. I received training in the use of a bullet matching algorithm. This is an algorithm that evaluates the characteristics of two fired bullets, in order to produce a score for the similarity of the bullets, where more similar bullets are more likely to have been fired from the same gun. I attended a workshop on the algorithm on 1/11/2020, held by CSAFE - Center for Statistics and Applications in Forensic Evidence. The training taught me to use the algorithm alongside my personal judgement. I found that my conclusion was reflected in the similarity score produced by the algorithm in all 21 cases.

combined: Where does the bullet matching algorithm come from?

combined: It was created by Dr. Adrian Jones.

combined: How long have the state police been using the bullet matching algorithm?

combined: Have you testified in court previously using the bullet matching algorithm?

combined: Yes, I have, approximately 10 times.

combined: As a firearms examiner, have you testified about your conclusions, given the results of your testing?

Text: Your Honor, at this time I would ask that Terry Smith be qualified as an opinion witness in the field of firearms identification subject to cross examination.
combined: Your Honor, at this time I would ask that Terry Smith be qualified as an opinion witness in the field of firearms identification subject to cross examination.

Text: Any cross on their credentials?
combined: Any cross on their credentials?

Speaker: Pros
Text: What work did you do on this case?
combined: What work did you do on this case?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I was asked to compare a bullet from the crime scene to a test fire from the gun recovered from the traffic stop.
combined: I was asked to compare a bullet from the crime scene to a test fire from the gun recovered from the traffic stop.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Did you examine how many lands and grooves the bullet had?
combined: Did you examine how many lands and grooves the bullet had?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes.
combined: Yes.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Can you explain for the jury what that means?
combined: Can you explain for the jury what that means?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes. In the interior of a barrel there are raised portions called lands and depressed areas called grooves. When a bullet passes down the barrel, a bullet will spin and that gives it stability and accuracy over a distance. Those raised areas are designed by the manufacturer. They're cut into the barrel. And each particular file has a different combination of lands and grooves. But essentially what those lands do is grip a bullet and spin it, and as that bullet passes down the barrel, it scratches the random imperfections of that barrel into the bullet.
combined: Yes. In the interior of a barrel there are raised portions called lands and depressed areas called grooves. When a bullet passes down the barrel, a bullet will spin and that gives it stability and accuracy over a distance. Those raised areas are designed by the manufacturer. They're cut into the barrel. And each particular file has a different combination of lands and grooves. But essentially what those lands do is grip a bullet and spin it, and as that bullet passes down the barrel, it scratches the random imperfections of that barrel into the bullet.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Now, for these bullets, you counted up the lands and grooves and determined the direction of the twist, correct?
combined: Now, for these bullets, you counted up the lands and grooves and determined the direction of the twist, correct?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes. This bullet had six lands. And the interior of the barrel, the barrel will either twist right or it will twist left. And in this particular case, the barrel twists right. And you can see that by looking at the bullet. If you look at the base of the bullet, either it goes to the left or goes to the right.
combined: Yes. This bullet had six lands. And the interior of the barrel, the barrel will either twist right or it will twist left. And in this particular case, the barrel twists right. And you can see that by looking at the bullet. If you look at the base of the bullet, either it goes to the left or goes to the right.

Text: Exhibit A depicts a cross-section of a barrel, where rifling is clearly present. Exhibit B depicts an example of a fired bullet, with which includes lands and grooves.
combined: Exhibit A depicts a cross-section of a barrel, where rifling is clearly present. Exhibit B depicts an example of a fired bullet, with which includes lands and grooves.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Can you describe the process of obtaining these test-fired bullets?
combined: Can you describe the process of obtaining these test-fired bullets?

Speaker: Fire
Text: The test-fired bullets came from a test fire of the gun recovered from the traffic stop.
combined: The test-fired bullets came from a test fire of the gun recovered from the traffic stop.

Speaker: Pros
Text: You mentioned test firings; can you explain what that means?
combined: You mentioned test firings; can you explain what that means?

Speaker: Fire
Text: In test firing, first what I would do is make sure the firearm is safe to actually test fire. Then I would use lab ammunition and I would test fire it, meaning that I am creating a fired bullet. Typically you do two at a time. That way you have a fired bullet to compare to another fired bullet.
combined: In test firing, first what I would do is make sure the firearm is safe to actually test fire. Then I would use lab ammunition and I would test fire it, meaning that I am creating a fired bullet. Typically you do two at a time. That way you have a fired bullet to compare to another fired bullet.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Would you then have taken the test firings you created and did you compare those test firings to the fired evidence that you had also received?
combined: Would you then have taken the test firings you created and did you compare those test firings to the fired evidence that you had also received?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes. First what I would do is compare my test shot to test shot. I am looking for a detailed microscopic pattern. Once I have done that then I would compare it to the fired evidence.
combined: Yes. First what I would do is compare my test shot to test shot. I am looking for a detailed microscopic pattern. Once I have done that then I would compare it to the fired evidence.

Speaker: Pros
Text: And how about the number of lands and direction of twist for the test fires?
combined: And how about the number of lands and direction of twist for the test fires?

Speaker: Fire
Text: It also had six lands, and twisted to the right.
combined: It also had six lands, and twisted to the right.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Okay. Now, did you compare the test-fired bullets to the fired evidence under the comparison microscope?
combined: Okay. Now, did you compare the test-fired bullets to the fired evidence under the comparison microscope?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, I did.
combined: Yes, I did.

Speaker: Pros
Text: What is your conclusion?
combined: What is your conclusion?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I found that there were sufficient individualizing characteristics to make an identification, that is that the two bullets were fired from the same barrel.
combined: I found that there were sufficient individualizing characteristics to make an identification, that is that the two bullets were fired from the same barrel.

Speaker: Pros
Text: How were you able to conclude that?
combined: How were you able to conclude that?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I found that the class characteristics of the two bullets were the same, but there was not sufficient agreement among the individual characteristics. My comparison was inconclusive.
combined: I found that the class characteristics of the two bullets were the same, but there was not sufficient agreement among the individual characteristics. My comparison was inconclusive.

Speaker: Pros
Text: How did you arrive at that decision?
combined: How did you arrive at that decision?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I found that there was significant disagreement in individual characteristics.
combined: I found that there was significant disagreement in individual characteristics.

Speaker: Pros
Text: How were you able to conclude that?
combined: How were you able to conclude that?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I place them under the comparison microscope, and I roll the bullet around until I can see the agreement in a particular area: unique surface contour that has sufficient agreement. At that point, when I've seen that, I start to rotate the bullets around and I look at all the different lands and grooves, impressions, for that unique detail. When I can see those, that agreement on multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as having sufficient agreement.
combined: I place them under the comparison microscope, and I roll the bullet around until I can see the agreement in a particular area: unique surface contour that has sufficient agreement. At that point, when I've seen that, I start to rotate the bullets around and I look at all the different lands and grooves, impressions, for that unique detail. When I can see those, that agreement on multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as having sufficient agreement.

Speaker: Fire
Text: When there is not strong agreement on multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as inconclusive.
combined: When there is not strong agreement on multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as inconclusive.

Speaker: Fire
Text: When I see disagreement in multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as having significant disagreement.
combined: When I see disagreement in multiple areas of the bullet, I identify the bullet as having significant disagreement.

Speaker: Fire
Text: Exhibit C shows an image of a comparison microscope, as well an an example of a matching bullet comparison.
combined: Exhibit C shows an image of a comparison microscope, as well an an example of a matching bullet comparison.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: ---Exhibit C---
combined: ---Exhibit C---

Pros
Text: Now, are you telling the jury today that in your opinion there's only one gun in the entire world that could have produced the markings that you saw on these bullets?
combined: Now, are you telling the jury today that in your opinion there's only one gun in the entire world that could have produced the markings that you saw on these bullets?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I'm saying that the probability that the two markings were made by different sources is so small that it is negligible.
combined: I'm saying that the probability that the two markings were made by different sources is so small that it is negligible.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Now, are you telling the jury today that when one firearm fires two bullets, the individual markings are so similar that you can say that they were fired from a single gun?
combined: Now, are you telling the jury today that when one firearm fires two bullets, the individual markings are so similar that you can say that they were fired from a single gun?

Speaker: Pros
Text: Now, are you telling the jury today that when one firearm fires two bullets, the individual markings are so similar that you can say that they were fired from a single gun?
combined: Now, are you telling the jury today that when one firearm fires two bullets, the individual markings are so similar that you can say that they were fired from a single gun?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, when there is significant similarity, the likelihood that two different guns could have made the mark is so remote as to be considered a practical impossibility.
combined: Yes, when there is significant similarity, the likelihood that two different guns could have made the mark is so remote as to be considered a practical impossibility.

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, when there is significant similarity, the likelihood that two different guns could have made the mark is so remote as to be considered a practical impossibility.
combined: Yes, when there is significant similarity, the likelihood that two different guns could have made the mark is so remote as to be considered a practical impossibility.

Speaker: Pros
Text: So that is not what you observed in this case?
combined: So that is not what you observed in this case?

Speaker: Pros
Text: So that is not what you observed in this case?
combined: So that is not what you observed in this case?

Speaker: Fire
Text: In this case, while the class markings were consistent, there was not significant similarity among the individual characteristics - leading to an inconclusive determination.
combined: In this case, while the class markings were consistent, there was not significant similarity among the individual characteristics - leading to an inconclusive determination.

Speaker: Fire
Text: In this case, the accidental, random marks on the bullets from the firing process were substantially different - enough so to conclude that the two bullets were likely fired from different guns.
combined: In this case, the accidental, random marks on the bullets from the firing process were substantially different - enough so to conclude that the two bullets were likely fired from different guns.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Did you use an algorithm to compare these bullets as well?
combined: Did you use an algorithm to compare these bullets as well?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Yes, I used the algorithm to compare the two test fires to each other. I also used the algorithm to compare the better marking test fire to the fired evidence that I received.
combined: Yes, I used the algorithm to compare the two test fires to each other. I also used the algorithm to compare the better marking test fire to the fired evidence that I received.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Could you explain how this algorithm compares bullets?
combined: Could you explain how this algorithm compares bullets?

Speaker: Fire
Text: The algorithm uses 3D measurements to make a comparison between the surface contours of each of the lands on each bullet. These comparisons result in a match score between 0 and 1, where 1 indicates a clear match, and 0 indicates that there is not a match. The bullet is aligned based on the maximum agreement between the lands, and the average match score for the lands is computed. This average score gives an overall match score for the entire bullet.
combined: The algorithm uses 3D measurements to make a comparison between the surface contours of each of the lands on each bullet. These comparisons result in a match score between 0 and 1, where 1 indicates a clear match, and 0 indicates that there is not a match. The bullet is aligned based on the maximum agreement between the lands, and the average match score for the lands is computed. This average score gives an overall match score for the entire bullet.

Text: What was the match score between the two test-fired bullets?
combined: What was the match score between the two test-fired bullets?

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score was 0.976.

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score was 0.034.
combined: The match score was 0.034.

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score was 0.34.

Text: What does this match score indicate about the bullets?
combined: What does this match score indicate about the bullets?

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score indicates that there is substantial similarity between the two bullets, which suggests that they were most likely fired from the same barrel.
combined: The match score indicates that there is substantial similarity between the two bullets, which suggests that they were most likely fired from the same barrel.

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score indicates that there is not sufficient agreement between the two bullets, which suggests that the results are inconclusive.
combined: The match score indicates that there is not sufficient agreement between the two bullets, which suggests that the results are inconclusive.

Speaker: Fire
Text: The match score indicates that there is significant disagreement between the two bullets.
combined: The match score indicates that there is significant disagreement between the two bullets.

combined: ---Exhibit E---

Speaker: Image
Image
Image
Pros
Text: How many times have you compared bullets to determine if they were fired from the same gun?
combined: How many times have you compared bullets to determine if they were fired from the same gun?

Speaker: Fire
Text: I'd say thousands.
combined: I'd say thousands.

Speaker: Pros
Text: And do you ever see two bullets that have agreement in every single area of the bullet?
combined: And do you ever see two bullets that have agreement in every single area of the bullet?

Speaker: Fire
Text: No. When firing a firearm there is a dynamic process because it is a contained explosion. When the firing pin hits the primer, which is basically the initiator, what gets it going, it will explode, burn the gun powder inside the casing, and the bullet will travel down the barrel, picking up the microscopic imperfections of the barrel, and the cartridge case will slam rearward against the support mechanism. During that dynamic process, each time it happens, a bullet will be marked slightly differently from one to the next.
combined: No. When firing a firearm there is a dynamic process because it is a contained explosion. When the firing pin hits the primer, which is basically the initiator, what gets it going, it will explode, burn the gun powder inside the casing, and the bullet will travel down the barrel, picking up the microscopic imperfections of the barrel, and the cartridge case will slam rearward against the support mechanism. During that dynamic process, each time it happens, a bullet will be marked slightly differently from one to the next.

combined: When you reached a conclusion, did you write up a report?

Text: Is it the local police department's protocol to have somebody else who's a firearms tool mark examiner in your lab review that report, review your work, and determine if it's correct?
combined: Is it the local police department's protocol to have somebody else who's a firearms tool mark examiner in your lab review that report, review your work, and determine if it's correct?

Speaker: Fire
Text: Peer review, yes.

Text: You have a criterion in your head, a subjective criterion, of what will constitute an identification. Is that correct?

Text: Yes.

Text: All right. If we brought three more people in, would their subjective criterion in their head be identical to yours?
combined: All right. If we brought three more people in, would their subjective criterion in their head be identical to yours?

Text: They would look for that same sufficient agreement. However, based on their training and experience on difficult comparisons, they may or may not come to the same decision.

Text: I understand, but that's the nature of being subjective, right?
combined: I understand, but that's the nature of being subjective, right?

Text: Right.
combined: Right.

Text: Is there something fixed about the amount of what has to be found to constitute sufficient agreement?
combined: Is there something fixed about the amount of what has to be found to constitute sufficient agreement?

Speaker: Fire
Text: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value.
combined: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value.

Text: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, a score above 0.8 is a general indicator of sufficient agreement.
combined: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, a score above 0.8 is a general indicator of sufficient agreement.

Speaker: Fire
Text: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, there is not a firm conclusion associated with values between 0.3 and 0.8.
combined: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, there is not a firm conclusion associated with values between 0.3 and 0.8.

Speaker: Fire
Text: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, a score below 0.3 is a general indicator of sufficient disagreement.
combined: No, there is not a fixed amount or a numerical value for my visual comparison. For the algorithm, however, a score below 0.3 is a general indicator of sufficient disagreement.

Text: You can't tell us anything about who shot the firearm, correct?

Speaker: Pros
Text: Could you describe how this bullet matching algorithm compares bullets?
combined: Could you describe how this bullet matching algorithm compares bullets?

Speaker: Alg
Text: Yes. For certain types of guns, the barrel will have lands and grooves, known as rifling. This rifling spins the bullet in order to make its trajectory more stable. Due to the manufacturing process, this rifling can produce identifiable markings on the bullet, based on random differences between barrels. Because of these random imperfections, the striation marks left on bullets can be compared in order to determine if it is likely that they were fired from the same gun.
combined: Yes. For certain types of guns, the barrel will have lands and grooves, known as rifling. This rifling spins the bullet in order to make its trajectory more stable. Due to the manufacturing process, this rifling can produce identifiable markings on the bullet, based on random differences between barrels. Because of these random imperfections, the striation marks left on bullets can be compared in order to determine if it is likely that they were fired from the same gun.

Speaker: Alg
Text: The first step is to determine where the lands on the bullet are located. These lands will be the sunken area that contains the striation marks between the smoother grooves. 3D scans are then taken for each land, and the “ shoulders ” , or area transitioning from the land to the grove, are excluded from the analysis.
combined: The first step is to determine where the lands on the bullet are located. These lands will be the sunken area that contains the striation marks between the smoother grooves. 3D scans are then taken for each land, and the “ shoulders ” , or area transitioning from the land to the grove, are excluded from the analysis.

Speaker: Alg
Text: Exhibit F shows the identification of a land.
combined: Exhibit F shows the identification of a land.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: ---Exhibit F---
combined: ---Exhibit F---

Speaker: Image
Alg
Text: Next, a stable area of the 3D scan containing the striations is selected, and a cross-section of this area is used to show the striations along with the topology of the region. A smoothing function is applied to remove some of the imaging noise from the 3D scan, leaving the striae intact. A second smooth is subtracted from the striations in order to remove the curvature of the region, leaving only the striae - this is what we call a signature.
combined: Next, a stable area of the 3D scan containing the striations is selected, and a cross-section of this area is used to show the striations along with the topology of the region. A smoothing function is applied to remove some of the imaging noise from the 3D scan, leaving the striae intact. A second smooth is subtracted from the striations in order to remove the curvature of the region, leaving only the striae - this is what we call a signature.

Speaker: Alg
Text: The signature for the two bullets being compared are aligned such that the best fit between the two signatures is achieved. The striation marks between the two signatures are then compared by evaluating how many of the high points and low points correspond. The algorithm can calculate the number of consecutively matching striations (CMS), or consecutively matching high points and low points - these are features used directly by some examiners to characterize the strength of a match. It also calculates the cross correlation between the two signatures, which is a numerical measure of the similarity between the two lands ranging between -1 and 1.
combined: The signature for the two bullets being compared are aligned such that the best fit between the two signatures is achieved. The striation marks between the two signatures are then compared by evaluating how many of the high points and low points correspond. The algorithm can calculate the number of consecutively matching striations (CMS), or consecutively matching high points and low points - these are features used directly by some examiners to characterize the strength of a match. It also calculates the cross correlation between the two signatures, which is a numerical measure of the similarity between the two lands ranging between -1 and 1.

Speaker: Alg
Text: Exhibit G shows two matching signatures, while Exhibit H shows two non-matching signatures.
combined: Exhibit G shows two matching signatures, while Exhibit H shows two non-matching signatures.

Speaker: Narrator
Text: ---Exhibit G---
combined: ---Exhibit G---

Speaker: Image
Narrator
Text: ---Exhibit H---
combined: ---Exhibit H---

Speaker: Image
Alg
Text: These traits are combined using what is known as a random forest. Each forest is composed of decision trees, which use a subset of the observed values in order to make a decision about whether or not the bullets constitute a match. The other observations are held out in order to determine an error rate. When the random forest makes a prediction, each decision tree “ votes ” , producing a numerical value between 0 and 1 corresponding to the proportion of trees which evaluate the features as being sufficiently similar to have come from the same source.
combined: These traits are combined using what is known as a random forest. Each forest is composed of decision trees, which use a subset of the observed values in order to make a decision about whether or not the bullets constitute a match. The other observations are held out in order to determine an error rate. When the random forest makes a prediction, each decision tree “ votes ” , producing a numerical value between 0 and 1 corresponding to the proportion of trees which evaluate the features as being sufficiently similar to have come from the same source.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Have you tested this algorithm?
combined: Have you tested this algorithm?

Speaker: Alg
Text: Yes. This algorithm was tested and validated on a number of different test sets of bullet scans. It was found that, as long as there are sufficient marks on the bullet, the algorithm could successfully distinguish between bullets fired by the same gun and those fired from different guns. Examiners' visual comparisons are also limited by the presence or absence of individualizing marks. Two test sets were using consecutively rifled barrels, which should be the most difficult to assess, and it was shown that the algorithm could distinguish between the bullets fired from two separate guns with complete accuracy.
combined: Yes. This algorithm was tested and validated on a number of different test sets of bullet scans. It was found that, as long as there are sufficient marks on the bullet, the algorithm could successfully distinguish between bullets fired by the same gun and those fired from different guns. Examiners' visual comparisons are also limited by the presence or absence of individualizing marks. Two test sets were using consecutively rifled barrels, which should be the most difficult to assess, and it was shown that the algorithm could distinguish between the bullets fired from two separate guns with complete accuracy.

Speaker: Alg
Text: Yes, this algorithm can be used on these types of bullets, given that this type of firearm marks well.
combined: Yes, this algorithm can be used on these types of bullets, given that this type of firearm marks well.

Speaker: Pros
Text: Has this algorithm been published?
combined: Has this algorithm been published?

Speaker: Alg
Text: Yes. The algorithm and its process have been discussed in peer reviewed journals such as Law, Probability, and Risk , The Annals of Applied Statistics , and Forensic Science International . The algorithm is also open source, which means that the full source code, documentation, and numerical weights are available online for anyone to examine.
combined: Yes. The algorithm and its process have been discussed in peer reviewed journals such as Law, Probability, and Risk , The Annals of Applied Statistics , and Forensic Science International . The algorithm is also open source, which means that the full source code, documentation, and numerical weights are available online for anyone to examine.

Speaker: Def
Text: This algorithm requires some decision making on the part of the operator, such as how much the signature is smoothed and what part of the bullets are inputted into the system, correct?
combined: This algorithm requires some decision making on the part of the operator, such as how much the signature is smoothed and what part of the bullets are inputted into the system, correct?

Speaker: Alg
Text: Yes, there are certain parameters which must be specified, but the system defaults are usually sufficient and have been validated with a number of different firearms and ammunition types. There are also operating protocols for determining which parts of the bullet are scanned, so while this process is manual, there are clear criteria and the associated variability from scanning is well understood, and published in Forensic Science International .

There are also operating protocols for determining which parts of the bullet are scanned, so while this process is manual, there are clear criteria and the associated variability from scanning is well understood, and published in Forensic Science International .

Speaker: Def
Text: Can this algorithm be applied to all bullets?
combined: Can this algorithm be applied to all bullets?

Speaker: Alg
Text: No, the algorithm only works on traditionally rifled bullets which are largely undamaged. The algorithm has not been validated to work on seriously damaged or fragmented bullets.
combined: No, the algorithm only works on traditionally rifled bullets which are largely undamaged. The algorithm has not been validated to work on seriously damaged or fragmented bullets.
